info.title: getting started
info.text: In this example I've created a custom animated cursor, hover over the blank page to see what the cursor looks like. If you've never created a custom cursor before, check out this example first. If you're new to CSS animations check out this example

info.title: custom cursor
info.text: As explained in the custom mouse cursor example, we can apply a custom cursor to our entire body by updating the cursor property using the CSS url() function. This won't animate the cursor though, for that we need to create a new CSS animation.

info.title: animation
info.text: As explained in the CSS animation example, we can create a new animation using the @keyframes at-rule, I've called mine "mini-cursors".

info.title: keyframes
info.text: I've got multiple different images in a folder called "minis", each representing a different frame in the animation. So in my CSS animation I'll create a keyframe for each which will update the CSS cursor property to the next image in the animation sequence.

info.title: apply animation
info.text: Lastly, we'll apply the animation to our entire body, we'll set the animation duration to 0.5s, or half a second, and the animation iteration count to infinite.

info.title: animation shorthand
info.text: You might have noticed that rather than declaring the animation-name, animation-duration and animation-iteration-count on seperate lines, as I did in the CSS animation example, here I wrote them on a single line using the animation property shorthand. You can learn more about it here.
